speaker: [Plays "Moanin'" by Ray Charles, from Genius+Soul=Jazz, Impulse! Records (1961). Personnel: Ray Charles: organ; Bobby Timmons: composer.]
words: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6BzkiZBzcu4

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: I guess you've heard that before, haven't you?

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Yeah, I like that. Ray Charles. A lot of bands have recorded that too, Bobby ought to be rich.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: How long has it been since you introduced that? You made the first record, didn't you?

speaker: Art Blakey
words: It's only four years, seems like longer, so much happened.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Yeah.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: You think that arrangement?

speaker: Art Blakey
words: He came up on, didn't he?

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah, he sure did.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: He was fooling around out there in Columbus, Ohio. He had been banging around the piano. We just had a rehearsal one day and put it together.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Is that right?

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Then he goes, "What was that?" Put it together. He made Bobby put it together because he wasn't going to do it. He was thinking about, I don't know. He was just messing around with some chords.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: And he put it together, it was a good thing.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Do you think this arrangement got the right spirit with feelings of...

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Yeah, for a big band I think it was wonderful at the time, that they had been playing it together. Of course we play it over every night and it begins to be better.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Gels, yeah.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Gels. And the way that Benny and Lee would work together on it, how they attacked. It's not as many people.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah, that's easier to get them...closer together

speaker: Art Blakey
words: It's easier to do it, yeah.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Do you think it was pretty good considering that?

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Yeah. It's good for what they had to do, that's something.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: What do you say about three stars worth, good? It's a little rating you know. Five is the top.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Well, it's a good record, yeah. It's very good because I see him and I liked the way it went down.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah. All right, let me see. The guy got an exquisite arrangement.

speaker: [Plays "Evad Smurd" by Dave Bailey, from Gettin' into Somethin', Epic Records (1961). Personnel: Dave Bailey: drums; Clark Terry: trumpet, composer; Curtis Fuller: trombone.]
Unknown Speaker
words: All those pictures we haven't decided on them, so.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Oh, [crosstalk 00:13:14].

speaker: Unknown Speaker
words: I'll ask tonight and pick [crosstalk 00:13:14].

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Oh, that's right, you'll all be down to the public before you close anyway.

speaker: Unknown Speaker
words: Well, our problem is I have no...to get to them.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: All right, fine, sure. Yeah, there's no rush on that, anytime before you leave town.

speaker: Unknown Speaker
words: Yeah.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Did you say when that was, Art?

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Oh, I don't know.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: You start up thinking you know and changed your mind. Well anyhow.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: That's Clark Terry.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Sure enough, can't mistake him.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: No. Bobby Brookmeyer, isn't it?

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah, I haven't noticed him.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Bobby Brookmeyer, I think it is. I don't know.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: What did you think of it?

speaker: Art Blakey
words: I liked that, that's good.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Good drumming technique?

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Sure.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: The whole thing because, it was the...

speaker: Art Blakey
words: He had a hell of a beat, he had a good beat. He sounds like a lot of people I know.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: What groove would you say it is? What style of drums do you think he's listened to? He played disco, can't you tell.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Well, I think that he listened to everybody. I guess it's either O.C or Dave Bailey. It's either one of them two.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: That's right.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: It was O.C?

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: When he threw up I'll tell you who it was, it was one of those two though, you're right. What would you say> That they were just very efficient all-round drummers, or what?

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Sure. I know they were. I was thinking of that, it was O.C because of the arrangement, I know O.C writes.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah, all right.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Write things like that.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: That's true. How would you rate it?

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Is that it?

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: No. It's down on the floor somewhere, I'll get up. No, one is poor, two is fair, three is good, four is very good and five is sensational.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Well, it's four.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Four? All right. And the other one before, Moanin', what do you give that?

speaker: Art Blakey
words: That's four.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Four so far? Yeah, that was Dave Bailey. And of course Clark Terry. Just a moment.

speaker: [Plays "I Didn't Know What Time It Was" by Joe Morello, from It's About Time, RCA Victor (1962). Personnel: Joe Morello: drums; Manny Album: arranger.]
words: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ntV9M7txgCc

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Who was that? That sounds like Quincy's arrangement. [inaudible crosstalk]

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Well, the music in question, regardless of who it was. What did it lack, what did it have?

speaker: Art Blakey
words: It didn't lack anything. I guess that's the way they wanted to play it, but it didn't lack anything. I don't think big bands is for drummers, because he doesn't have enough freedom to do the things that you want to do, because I think it's too many personalities, or something, to fool with. We need them too, we need big bands but they are not together long enough to have that real feeling that a band should have. If we had big bands on the road like it used to be, the guys get to live with each other, then we have some big band music. But it's pretty hard to take a band and throw it together.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: That's what it sounds like.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: No, it sounds good, it sounds hitting together but you can tell that they haven't worked together.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: You're trying to make a good record date and it's very hard. I wish we had more big bands because it would be a school for the cats.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah, that's true.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: It would help so many young kids out, straighten them right up. It would help them but since we don't have them, pretty hard to put a date together.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: It was a good record.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Good record but it didn't gas you up inside.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Well, I think it was the tempo, it was changing too much for me.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: It's good but the tempo changes a little bit too much for me. Well, it's kind of hard to go from one extreme directly into another, unless you're going into a mambo or something.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Tasteful into another rhythm.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: I see what you mean, in other words change the meter as well as the tempo.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Yeah. He did it with, you know it gels pretty good in the opening. It sounds like Randy.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah. Did you want to pass on rating that?

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Because did would not be the way the cats write today. They write in one mood and then they go into another one, without upsetting the apple cart.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: A natural transition.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Yeah. To get into it.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Just let it go that, not rate it, we'll give it fair, two stars.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: It's a good arrangement, it was well played and I think they should get some...

speaker: [Play "Be-Bop" by Milt Jackson and John Coltrane, from Bags & Trane, Atlantic Records (1959). Personnel: Milt Jackson: vibes; John Coltrane: tenor saxophone; Hank Jones: piano; Paul Chambers: bass; Connie Kay: drums.]
words: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m6_3BiszoIU

speaker: Art Blakey
words: I haven't got the least idea what it is.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Nevermind that.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: I'd like to know.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Aha. Does it mean you liked it?

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Yeah.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Which did you like the best?

speaker: Art Blakey
words: What?

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Which of the guys did you like best? Or what did you like about it?

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Of this tune?

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: The rhythm section was good. We play, he was cooking. I don't know what was playing. Somebody I don't know.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: You liked all of them, all the solos?

speaker: Art Blakey
words: I didn't listen to the solos.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Really?

speaker: Art Blakey
words: No.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Too busy listening to the rhythm section?

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Yes, I was listening to the rhythm section. The solo is something I don't know what happened in there. It just didn't get my attention. The rhythm section had me that time.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Well, all right.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: I'm prejudiced.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: I guess it's [crosstalk 00:21:13].

speaker: Art Blakey
words: The rhythm section.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: So you didn't notice the [crosstalk 00:21:13]?

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Well I'll tell you what I like about horns. I think a man with his horn is like Bird said. What's in a man come out when he plays his instrument. He wasn't too positive about what he was doing because he would get that presence anytime you hear Fat Girl, or you hear Diz or you hear Miles. You've got to listen to them and it's all.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Clifford even wants to listen to him. Lee Morgan, these guys you've got to listen to. Freddie Hubbard, they command your attention while your listening. Not that it command your attention, but something happens. You can do it but this is very important. I think the guys playing the horn, he's got all the best of everything. You've got a melody instrument, you're supposed to get in there. If he don't, the rhythm section is cooking and right behind they're going to take it away from him, he's got no business up there.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: You've got that presence, you've got to have presence. Everybody can't but some guys do, be in a solo, some guys.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yes, that's right.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Most guys got it. You know Clark Terry, so that's something. Make you listen to him whatever he's playing.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Cullum got that. Benny Goodman had that too man, he make you listen to him.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Regardless of what he's doing. Pops got it. They just make you listen. I'll tell you what, you know what Leonard? You've got to hear Bud Powell.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Oh yes, he's still making them as well.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Oh, he's cooking.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: That's wonderful. I saw him in Paris about three years ago and he was in very good shape then.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Oh, he's in much better shape now.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Downstairs place, you know the...

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Uh, that's where he was working?

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: We've got a picture there, look at that pitcure, yeah. Two different men.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: How about that one?

speaker: Art Blakey
words: That was Buddy Rich, right?

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Well, partly. Art, do you want to hear some of it again?

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Yeah.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: It wasn't all Buddy Rich.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Oh?

words: Just a minute. [Plays excerpt from the same tune]. There you go now.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: That's Max and Buddy, right?

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: That's it.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Huh?

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: I'm not supposed to say anything, but you guessed it. Here you go. Did you ever hear that before, any of those things?

speaker: Art Blakey
words: No. Never heard that before.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: What do you think of the effect?

speaker: Art Blakey
words: The drumming part was good, come off good. And they made it on time, they made the fourth on time which is something. It isn't done, it's always done with exceptional people, exceptional drummers. Because most drummers can't cooperate like that, they try to outplay each other and they ain't cooperating. This was like they cooperated together.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah, that's right.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: It was nice, it was beautiful. So that's why I thought it was good.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Very good. The drumming part, what about the rest of it?

speaker: Art Blakey
words: I didn't...

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Pay too much mind?

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Too much attention to it.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Well it was pretty sloppy.

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Mm-hmm. Then again they had to get something together real quick.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah, I guess so. Do you like it or not?

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Yeah.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Do you want to say anything about either Max or Buddy individually?

speaker: Art Blakey
words: Well, I love both of them. Very tight, all of this. That's the way it is, it's a good thing that people get a chance to hear them together.

speaker: Leonard Feather
words: Yeah, that's right.
